record.title: Judge's House Kent Street (Building)
record.detail: Elegant home built for surveyor William Harper which is the only example of an 1820s Colonial Georgian single storey bungalow to survive in the city.

record.detail: Elegant home built for surveyor William Harper which is the only example of an 1820s Colonial Georgian single storey bungalow to survive in the city.

record.title: Sydney City Mission
record.detail: Appalled by the poverty he found in Sydney when he arrived in 1860, Benjamin Short founded the Sydney City Mission in 1862. While some of the problems it addressed changed over the years, the Mission's work for Sydney's most vulnerable people continues in 2009.

record.title: Hyndes, Thomas, Property, Owned, Judge's House Kent Street
Hyndes, Thomas (Person)
record.detail: Convict who became a wealthy timber merchant, miller and landowner and was responsible for the construction of St Thomas church at Enfield.

record.detail: Elegant home built for surveyor William Harper which is the only example of an 1820s Colonial Georgian single storey bungalow to survive in the city.

record.title: Hyndes, Lucy, Property, Owned, Judge's House Kent Street
Hyndes, Lucy (Person)
record.detail: Wealthy property owner in Pitt Street who inherited the properties upon her husband Thomas's death.

record.title: City Night Refuge and Soup Kitchen, Property, Occupied, Judge's House Kent Street
City Night Refuge and Soup Kitchen (Organisation)
record.detail: City Night Refuge and Soup Kitchen
Shelter and soup kitchen established in 1868 at The Judge's House, in Kent Street by a group of businessmen. It was taken over by the Sydney City Mission in 1945.

record.title: Sydney City Mission, Property, Occupied, Judge's House Kent Street
Sydney City Mission (Organisation)
record.detail: Philanthropic organisation formed to provide welfare to Sydneysiders living in poverty, which was absorbed by the umbrella organisation Mission Australia in 1996.

record.title: Occupied
record.detail: Commonly pertains to an organisation occupying a site.

record.title: Sydney soup kitchen 1883
State Library of Victoria
record.detail: The State Library of Victoria is contributing items from its multimedia collection
The Australasian sketcher with pen and pencil, 4 June 1883 p 96

DEFAULT IMG Also in Australasian Sketcher, 4 June 1883, p96 http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-page5738964, description here: http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-page5738963 Building was in Kent Street, opened on 1 July 1868 as the City Night Refuge and Soup Kitchen. P-ID: 10320
P-DoS Notes: The Sydney soup kitchen. 
Description
Men seated round a wooden table eating a meal: inset of exterior of building. IspartOf Illustrated newspaper file. Australasian sketcher.
Date or place
 June 4, 1883.
P-Related: Ch

record.title: Suburban
record.detail: Before the emergence of the welfare state in the twentieth century, economic downturns saw thousands struggling to exist, and their needs were usually met by private charities.
IMG City Night Refuge OR Soup Kitchen (1868), OR new shelters for homeless men were opened by the Central Methodist Mission in 1908 and Salvation Army in 1912.

record.title: ends
record.detail: With high unemployment rates in the 1890s, many were dependent on the philanthropy of organisations like the City Night Refuge and Soup Kitchen for meals and somewhere to sleep.

record.title: City Night Refuge and Soup Kitchen (Organisation)
record.detail: City Night Refuge and Soup Kitchen
Shelter and soup kitchen established in 1868 at The Judge's House, in Kent Street by a group of businessmen. It was taken over by the Sydney City Mission in 1945.

record.title: two
record.detail: Poverty remained a problem in late nineteenth century Sydney, with thousands supported on 'outdoor relief', like these recipients seen in Sydney streets in 1885.
